hints_html: An equilibrium probability vector is one such that if you were try to perform a transition, it wouldn’t move. Physically it represents the final probabilities of ending up in a given state from any initial state.

question: A 24
sols_html:
From the hint we see that a probability equilibrium vector gives us the probabilities of a final state from any initial state. This means that once we transition to a certain point, further transitions do not impact the probability any more. Let’s assume we have reached this special equilibrium vector v then

\[\begin{aligned} P\mathbf{v}=\mathbf{v}\end{aligned}\]

which says exactly what we stated; attempting to transition v does nothing to it. Therefore the special vector v, will satisfy

\[\begin{aligned} (P-I)\mathbf{v}&=\mathbf{0}\\ \begin{bmatrix} -2/10 & 3/10 & 1/10\\ 2/10 & -7/10 & 7/10\\ 0 & 4/10 & -8/10 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} v_1\\ v_2\\ v_3 \end{bmatrix} &=\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

which we can solve (using Gaussian elimination) to get, for a free parameter, t,

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{v}=\left[\frac{7}{2}t,2t,t\right].\end{aligned}\]

Now recall that the input vector v is a set of probabilities and so the entries of v must sum to 1. Therefore we have that,

\[\begin{aligned} v_1+v_2+v_3=\frac{7}{2}t+2t+t=\frac{13}{2}t=1\end{aligned}\]

and therefore, t=2/13 so that our equilibrium vector v is

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{v}=\left[\frac{7}{13},\frac{4}{13},\frac{2}{13}\right].\end{aligned}\]

Note (This is not necessary to answer the question): Our result means that starting from any initial state, we will end up in state 1 with a probability of 7/13, state 2 with a probability of 4/13 and state 3 with a probability of 2/13. If we try this with our initial state from A 23, [0,1,0] we notice that after 8 transitions,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}P^8[0,1,0]=[0.5309904100,0.3114556300,0.1575539600]\end{aligned}\]

where our equilibrium vector is

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{v}=[0.5384615385,0.3076923077,0.1538461538]\end{aligned}\]

which is already a fairly good agreement!

Note further: It may have crossed some minds that the equilibrium vector is always the eigenvector for the transition matrix corresponding to an eigenvalue of 1, whose entries sum to 1. For probability matrices where the columns sum to 1 there will always be such a vector.

statement_html:
Questions A22-A24 concern a random walk with three states that has transition matrix

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{c c c} 8/10 & 3/10 & 1/10 \\ 2/10 & 3/10 & 7/10 \\ 0 & 4/10 & 2/10 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

What is the equilibrium probability vector for the random walk?
